June 8 at 12:43 PM ·

New at The Yadkin Center - Central Sterile Processing

Are you looking for a new career in health care? Surry Community College's Central Sterile Processing course leads to certification through the International Association of Healthcare Central Service Material Management.

It's a new course offering for Surry Community College at The Yadkin Center from July 7 - Nov. 19 on Tuesdays and Thursdays, from 5:30 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. Seven Saturdays (7 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.) will be required in order to gain valuable hands-on experience. Class cost is $257 along with an exam fee of $120.

Register for the class online at: https://surry.edu/areas-of-study/job-training/allied-health

To learn more, contact Debbie Cave at (336) 386-3372 or caved@surry.edu or Margie Collins at (336) 386-3423 or collinsmh@surry.edu.

Due to COVID-19 pandemic, the schedule may change or go online.

Mebane Foundation
May 17, 2019 at 9:46 AM ·

Please share and help us get the word out. The Mebane Foundation partnership with Yadkin County Schools is growing!

“The Foundation’s ability to be a catalyst for innovation and excellence in education would not be possible without the opportunities that Yadkin County created for Unifi to be a successful company,” said William Mebane, Foundation board member and Unifi employee.

Mr. Mebane founded Unifi nearly fifty years ago with Yadkin County as the epicenter of its global operations. He cared deeply for Unifi and the community as a whole, so it makes sense for the Foundation and Yadkin County Schools to further strengthen our partnership for the future.

The Foundation’s board voted unanimously at its most-recent semi-annual meeting to award an additional $57,000 to the Yadkin County School System for the coming year.

For the complete story please visit http://www.mebanefoundation.com/yadkin-county-school-system/yadkin-county-schools-and-mebane-foundation-strengthen-partnership/

post_text: Good morning. This is Superintendent Todd Martin. We have been out checking conditions since early this morning. At this point, we know of at least 13 roads that are closed. While none of the major roads in the county are closed, several of the roads that are closed are heavily traveled by buses. Additionally, we still have a school that does not have power and none of our schools have internet. Therefore, I feel it is best for schools to be closed for students today. Out of school time programs are open and will operate on the normal schedule today. It will be an optional workday for teachers with a reporting time of 9:00. It will be a no day for teacher assistants. We do feel like most of the roads that are currently closed will be open later on in the day but at this point we need to allow time for water to recede and the roads to be cleared. Again, I appreciate your patience as we work through this.

post_text: Good afternoon. This is Superintendent Todd Martin. Initially the weather forecast had the storm moving southeast of Raleigh but it has shifted and is now projected to move northwest of Raleigh. With the shift has come increased rain and wind gusts. The worst of the rain and wind gusts are forecast to happen this afternoon between 1:00 and 3:00. Therefore, rather than release early and put our buses and student drivers out during the worst time, I made the decision to keep students in school where I know they are safe. We are planning to evaluate weather conditions as we approach our regular dismissal time of 3:00. If conditions have not improved I plan to keep students in school past dismissal time. If that becomes necessary I will send another message letting you know that we plan to hold students and I will try to provide an estimated time of dismissal. I know this will create an inconvenience for many, but providing for the safety of our students is my top concern. Thank you.
